G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Lowell District Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19A and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the property is located in Lowell, Massachusetts and the Defendant resides or conducts business there.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Lowell District Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19A and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the property is located in Lowell, Massachusetts and the Defendant resides or conducts business there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: The amount in controversy does not exceed $7,000, thus falling within the civil jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises” under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s failure to correct hazardous conditions and maintain proper ventilation violates the sanitary code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq., evidencing interference with quiet enjoyment. See *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u00a7 410.500\u2013410.proposition: The Massachusetts sanitary code provisions at 105 C.M.R. §§ 410.500–410.550 require bathrooms to be adequately ventilated and free from chronic dampness; Defendant’s refusal to correct deficient ventilation violates those standards. See *Hastings v. Taylor*, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 535 (1997).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when a landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises. *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment based on the landlord’s conduct or omissions that naturally and probably result in substantial interference with the tenants’ use of the premises. It holds that, even without intent to evict, the landlord’s introduction and permitting of a noisy lounge, where the landlord had the right and ability to control the disturbance, violated the tenants’ quiet enjoyment and amounted to constructive eviction. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s acts or omissions that substantially interfere with use and enjoyment breach the covenant.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when a landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises. *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the covenant/statutory concept of quiet enjoyment and explains that liability arises when the landlord’s conduct or omissions result in serious interference with the tenant’s tenancy, adopting the “natural and probable consequence” standard and citing Blackett v. Olanoff with approval. The court applies this to repeated flooding that impaired the apartment’s habitability and explicitly affirms that such interferences fall within “quiet enjoyment,” even though it ultimately vacates the separate quiet-enjoyment damages as duplicative. Thus the case supports the proposition that substantial interference with use and enjoyment constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Id.… The jury found…that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”} жд```**Note**: The relevant excerpt slightly exceeds 100 words to preserve full context.```  (The last sentence marker and note are not part of the structured JSON.)```

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: The presence of mold and the landlord’s failure to remediate environmental or habitability issues constitute substantial interference. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (failure to remedy unsanitary and unsafe conditions violates quiet enjoyment).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The case does interpret the quiet enjoyment statute and notes that failure to repair known defects can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not mention mold or environmental conditions generally, nor does it hold that the mere presence of a hazardous condition plus failure to remediate automatically constitutes substantial interference. Instead, the court emphasizes that at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know of the condition is required, and specifically rejects strict liability under § 14 based solely on a statutory violation. Thus, citing Al‑Ziab for the broad proposition about mold and habitability issues overstates what the case decides.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 378.proposition: The presence of mold and the landlord’s failure to remediate environmental or habitability issues constitute substantial interference. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (failure to remedy unsanitary and unsafe conditions violates quiet enjoyment).
*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 378.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that the landlord’s failure to repair serious physical defects (here, a leaky roof causing water intrusion) both breached the implied warranty of habitability and interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While mold is not mentioned, the decision stands for the broader principle that failure to remedy unsanitary or unsafe physical conditions that substantially impair habitability constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment, consistent with the proposition cited.
*Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 378.relevant_excerpt: The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises... Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all "actual and consequential damages" where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s failure to correct hazardous conditions and maintain proper ventilation violates the sanitary code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq., evidencing interference with quiet enjoyment. See *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses extensive State Sanitary Code violations (heat, windows, infestation, etc.) as part of the factual background and as supporting breach of the implied warranty of habitability and c. 93A liability. However, the decision never analyzes 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq. directly nor links ventilation or correction of hazardous conditions specifically to a statutory claim of interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The holding focuses on c. 93A emotional distress damages and warranty of habitability damages, not on sanitary-code-based quiet enjoyment violations, so it does not support the proposition as worded.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.... The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects... and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s conduct is an “indirect act” that constitutes interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not analyze or characterize this failure as an “indirect act” of interference. The court focuses on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences, not on any distinction between direct versus indirect interference. Therefore, the case supports liability under § 14 for failure to provide heat, but not specifically the proposition that such conduct is an “indirect act” of interference.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, which impose civil liability on a landlord ‘who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish . . . heat. . . or . . . who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . .’ … A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Under *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), landlords are liable under § 14 even where the interference results from neglect or failure to correct known defects.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: This opinion is about rent abatement under the warranty of habitability, not about statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court holds landlords are strictly liable for rent abatement once they have notice of uninhabitable conditions, regardless of fault or reasonable repair efforts. It does not construe § 14 or discuss landlord liability for interference with quiet enjoyment under that statute, so it cannot be cited as authority for § 14 liability based on neglect or failure to correct known defects.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.… Considerations of fault do not belong in an analysis of warranty.… [T]he warranty of habitability is not designed to penalize the landlord for misbehavior.”

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: The existence of mold and the uninhabitable condition further violate the implied warranty of habitability, *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), which supports and parallels the claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent focused on how to conceptualize the landlord’s obligations (implied warranty of habitability vs. implied agreement to comply with the State Sanitary Code). It does discuss habitability and code violations generally, but it does not mention mold, nor does it connect habitability violations to G.L. c. 186, § 14 or characterize such conditions as violations of that statute. Using this passage to say that mold and uninhabitable conditions ‘further violate the implied warranty of habitability’ and ‘support and parallel’ a claim under c. 186, § 14 overstates what this opinion actually holds or squarely addresses.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court in the present cases does not discuss or otherwise deal with the rule quoted above from Palmigiani v. D’Argento… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant… that the unit complies with those standards…”

*Hastings v. Taylor*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts sanitary code provisions at 105 C.M.R. §§ 410.500–410.550 require bathrooms to be adequately ventilated and free from chronic dampness; Defendant’s refusal to correct deficient ventilation violates those standards. See *Hastings v. Taylor*, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 535 (1997).
*Hastings v. Taylor*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Colley v. Benson, Young & Downs Insurance
*Hastings v. Taylor*, 42 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The provided text of Hastings v. Taylor concerns Rule 60(b) relief from a judgment, focusing on personal jurisdiction, subject matter jurisdiction, due process, and attorney authorization. It does not discuss the Massachusetts sanitary code or any requirements regarding bathroom ventilation or chronic dampness. Therefore, this case cannot serve as authority for the cited sanitary code proposition, and the citation is inaccurate or misplaced for that purpose.
